dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A lot of people think that if you copy any code, it's automatically copyright infringement, but the Supreme Court just ruled otherwise in a huge case involving Microsoft and Oracle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A lot of people think that if you copy any code, it's automatically copyright infringement, but the Supreme Court just ruled otherwise in a huge case involving Microsoft and Oracle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oracle alleged that Google had infringed its copyright when it copied some elements of code from Java, which is owned by Oracle, to build its Android operating system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and specifically, they were looking at those 11,500 lines of Java code that Microsoft used in Windows. Oracle was not happy about that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and specifically, they were looking at those eleven thousand, five hundred lines of Java code that Microsoft used in Windows. Oracle was not happy about that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The dispute centered on around 11,500 lines of code that were from Java. Oracle alleged that Google had infringed its copyright when it copied some elements of code from Java, which is owned by Oracle, to build its Android operating system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the court decided it was fair use, which is a big deal because APIs—those code connectors between programs—are used all the time by developers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the court decided it was fair use, which is a big deal because APIs-those code connectors between programs-are used all the time by developers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a 6-to-2 outcome, the Supreme Courts justices rejected a lower court decision in Oracles favor, ruling instead that Googles copying of the pieces of code known as application programming interfaces, or APIs, was fair use.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, um, if Oracle had won, it could've set off a ton of lawsuits over API usage everywhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, um, if Oracle had won, it could've set off a ton of lawsuits over A P I usage everywhere.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Had the court ruled in Oracles favor, it could have unleashed a tsunami of litigation as other companies sought to extract payment for use of their own APIs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Justice Scalia wrote the majority opinion, saying Microsoft only took what was needed for a "transformative program."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Justice Scalia wrote the majority opinion, saying Microsoft only took what was needed for a transformative program.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The author of the majority opinion, Justice Stephen Breyer, wrote that Google had copied only what was needed to allow users to put their accrued talents to work in a new and transformative program.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interestingly, uh, kind of protects innovation instead of blocking it. The ruling was super close though—5 to 4.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interestingly, uh, kind of protects innovation instead of blocking it. The ruling was super close thoughminus five to four.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a 6-to-2 outcome, the Supreme Courts justices rejected a lower court decision in Oracles favor, ruling instead that Googles copying of the pieces of code known as application programming interfaces, or APIs, was fair use.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the dissent, led by Justice Thomas, argued Oracle's code wasn't even copyrightable to begin with.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the dissent, led by Justice Thomas, argued Oracle's code wasn't even copyrightable to begin with.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the dissenting opinion, Justice Thomas argued that Oracles code was copyrightable and that Googles use of it in Android was anything but fair.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the court didn't actually settle that bigger question, did they? They just assumed it was protected for the sake of the fair use argument.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the court didn't actually settle that bigger question, did they? They just assumed it was protected for the sake of the fair use argument.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The outcome of the case leaves a crucial question unanswered: whether API code is in fact eligible for copyright protection at all. Instead, it worked on the assumption that Oracles code was in fact eligible for protection.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so future cases might have to tackle whether APIs can be copyrighted at all. It's a bit of a cliffhanger.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so future cases might have to tackle whether APIs can be copyrighted at all. It's a bit of a cliffhanger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Microsoft was seeking up to $9 billion in this, which is just… massive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Microsoft was seeking up to nine dollars billion in this, which is just... massive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The ruling is a huge setback for Oracle, which had claimed up to $9 billion in damages for breach of its intellectual property.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Huge. Meanwhile, Google's statement called it a loss for interoperability and developers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huge. Meanwhile, Google's statement called it a loss for interoperability and developers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Google said the courts opinion was a victory for consumers, interoperability and computer science, and that it gives legal certainty to the next generation of developers whose new products and services will benefit consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But honestly, for most software companies, this ruling is a relief. Copying APIs is just standard practice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But honestly, for most software companies, this ruling is a relief. Copying APIs is just standard practice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The case had been closely watched within the software industry because copying of APIs, which are key blocks of code that allow different software applications to talk to one another and exchange information, is a common practice amongst developers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It keeps the door open for new apps and services without constant legal threats.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It keeps the door open for new apps and services without constant legal threats.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, you gotta wonder if this will encourage more companies to push boundaries with similar cases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, you gotta wonder if this will encourage more companies to push boundaries with similar cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. The Supreme Court might be revisiting this sooner than we think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. The Supreme Court might be revisiting this sooner than we think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If more cases involving APIs end up being litigated, it may not be long before the Supreme Courts justices find themselves having to tackle that bigger issue too.
